channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: South Africa Is Not a Metaphor
item.description: The country’s story of liberation has been both a symbol of hope and a burden. Now it’s time for reality.

item.title: South Africa Election: ANC Loses Majority for the First Time in 30 Years
item.description: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.

item.title: Live Nation reveals ‘a criminal threat actor’ offered to sell Ticketmaster data on the dark web, while reports say hackers seek $500,000 for customer info
item.description: The data reportedly includes names, addresses, phone numbers and some credit card details of millions of Ticketmaster customers.

item.title: South Africa Election: ANC Loses Majority for the First Time in 30 Years
item.description: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.

item.title: U Tin Oo, Embattled Pro-Democracy Leader in Myanmar, Dies at 97
item.description: Once one of his country’s most powerful figures, he helped found its main opposition party. “I had to face up to the harm I did to people when I served in the army,” he said.

item.title: The housing market is finally seeing more inventory, but buyers aren’t showing up as a ‘cold reality is settling down’
item.description: “Without the rate cuts, a cold reality is settling down on the housing market,” Robert Frick, corporate economist for Navy Federal Credit Union, said.

item.title: After Pipes Burst in Atlanta, Many Residents Lose Water, Then Patience
item.description: Major main breaks resulted in closed businesses, canceled events and angry residents who were upset over a lack of updates.

item.title: Robert Pickton, Notorious Canadian Serial Killer, Dies at 74
item.description: Convicted in the murder of six women (though he boasted of killing many more), he died of unspecified injuries after being assaulted in prison.

item.title: The best-performing stock on the S&P 500 is a ‘unicorn’ that joined the index less than a month ago and is beating Nvidia
item.description: Vistra’s mix of gas and nuclear power plants make it “a unicorn,” according to Guggenheim’s Shahriar Pourreza.

item.title: After Biden’s Push for Truce, Netanyahu Calls Israel’s War Plans Unchanged
item.description: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Netanyahu Answers Biden’s Calls for Truce by Insisting on ‘Destruction’ of Hamas
item.description: The Israeli leader did not explicitly endorse or reject a proposal outlined by Mr. Biden, but the timing of his remarks seemed to put the brakes on hopes for a speedy resolution.

item.title: The ANC party that freed South Africa from apartheid loses its 30-year majority, signaling first-ever coalition government to come
item.description: With more than 99% of votes counted, the once-dominant ANC had received just over 40% in Wednesday's election.

item.title: Congestion Pricing Could Bring Cleaner Air. But Maybe Not for Everyone.
item.description: Officials expect New York City’s new tolling system to reduce air pollution, as well as carbon emissions. The impact may be uneven.

item.title: After Biden’s Push for Truce, Netanyahu Calls Israel’s War Plans Unchanged
item.description: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.

item.title: Jerome Powell's Federal Reserve is stuck in a self-defeating paradox that makes cutting rates more difficult, economist warns
item.description: "You can call this the Fed Cut Reflexivity Paradox: The more the Fed insists that the next move in interest rates is a cut, the more financial conditions will ease, making it more difficult for the Fed to cut."
